Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: BCC: Developing a Research Community and Capacity for the Study of Cultural Heritage in Conflict

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cultural heritage represents the physical manifestation of the culture and history of a social group or region and forms a major component of a people's sense of identity. Intentional destruction of cultural heritage during intrastate and ethnonationalist conflict is a well-known but rarely studied phenomenon often designed to erase the presence and history of a rival social or ethnic group. Recent cases of such destruction include the 2001 demolition of the Bamiyan Buddhas in Afghanistan, the 2006 bombing of the al-Askari Mosque in Iraq, and the 2012 destruction of Sufi shrines in Timbuktu, Mali. Despite considerable scholarship about purposeful violations of civil and political rights during conflict, there is a general tendency to view damage to cultural heritage as an unfortunate collateral outcome, rather than as a deliberate tactic. Consequently, few studies have examined how damage to cultural heritage sites is linked to ethnic or sectarian violence. Understanding how heritage destruction is implicated in the trajectory of these conflicts will enable U.S. policymakers and other humanitarian agencies working in conflict zones to design more effective interventions.

This interdisciplinary project will convene a working group consisting of subject matter experts in archaeology, anthropology, and other allied fields; specialists in conflict studies from political science, geography, and sociology; and methodological experts from the data sciences. Over the course of a two-year period, this research community will develop common definitions and coding standards that will enable the future development of large-scale datasets documenting and quantifying the destruction of cultural heritage. In order to facilitate such a comparative study, there is a need to develop methods for integrating data about events, specific localities, historical trajectories, and social conditions that precipitate acute outbreaks of destructive violence, which includes damage to cultural heritage. The proposed coding standards will be evaluated with a proof-of-concept case study based upon the current conflict in Syria. The completion of this test dataset will establish best practices in coding cultural heritage destruction information as well as a case study on the relationship between sectarian violence and cultural heritage destruction. Findings of the study, as well as an assessment of the validity and reliability of the coding strategy will be made available through a web portal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has explored the data needs for future research about the intentional destruction of cultural heritage during periods of conflict. It had two primary goals: 1) to identify a community of scholars in the social sciences committed to studying this topic provided that reliable data could be made available; 2) to create standards for coding event-level data and geospatial imagery about cultural destruction for the purpose of future large-scale data development. To meet these aims, this project involved 24 advisory workshops with the relevant stakeholder research communities—among them anthropologists, archaeologists, geographers, political scientists, and experts in international relations to determine how to proceed with interdisciplinary research between these fields and how to gather data that could be employed in future research by the various disciplines. The result has been the establishment of an international, cross-disciplinary research group of 16 international universities and research organizations called the “Conflict Culture Research Network” (CCRN), the creation of a geospatial ontology for coding instances of cultural destruction, the development of interoperable coding standards for the event-level destruction of cultural heritage based upon the Uppsala Conflict Data Program, and the completion of a proof-of-concept event-level dataset of approximately 650 instances of cultural heritage destruction in Syria for the period of 2011-2014.


Due to increasing public awareness about cultural heritage destruction in Syria and Iraq after this project began in 2014, the CCRN has generated significant public attention apart from the research stakeholders. Publicity surrounding the project resulted in significant media attention, which disseminated the results of the research to the general public. The most prominent example of this was the project’s inclusion in a documentary film, “The Destruction of Memory,” which was produced by Australian director Tim Slade, and which featured imagery produced by the AAAS Geospatial Technologies Project, alongside interviews with co-PIs Susan Wolfinbarger (AAAS) and Corine Wegener (Smithsonian). Brian I. Daniels (Penn), Corine Wegener, Susan Wolfinbarger, and Katharyn Hanson (Penn) also presented at a congressional briefing about cultural heritage destruction, during which this project was discussed. Additionally, data collected during this project was supplied to the U.S. Department of State as evidence to support Secretary Kerry’s statement about genocide in Iraq and Syria.

Throughout this project, consultations and workgroup meetings have included both qualitative and quantitative analysts, who have expressed great enthusiasm about the development of new, collaborative research projects. The CCRN will provide a platform for these conversations to develop and to continue. The group now has its own web presence for recruiting additional research collaborators, disseminating coding standards, and sharing research results. The coding-standards, and test-cases demonstrating proof-of-concept of those standards, are now in preparation for publication. Finally, this project has shown that it is possible to collect and code event-level and geospatial data about cultural heritage destruction that are interoperable with conflict research. The synergy of these topics, and the potential that a comprehensive dataset of event-level cultural heritage destruction could be collected systematically for additional conflicts, promises to contribute to our knowledge about the social dynamics that implicate culture and heritage during periods of violence.
